Good heavens! what can he mean? [Aſide.] Sir, I muſt confeſs you are a little ambiguous; but, to prevent every poſſibility of miſtake, I will be very explicit. I have inveſted the whole of my property in
bank ſtock—I have immediate occaſion for one thouſand pounds, for which I will give my note; there are ſome formalities attendant on drawing money out of our public repoſitories, which I am willing to ſpare myſelf; and, if you can conveniently furniſh we with this ſum on my engagement that it ſhall be returned to you in one month, the purpoſe, the whole purpoſe [bowing] of my viſit here this morning, will be pleaſingly anſwered.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Is that all? [Aſide.] Madam, I am happy—I had thought—I, I, I, am extremely happy, upon my ſoul, and I will fetch you the bills immediately. Well, I am greatly relieved. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Well, this is ſingular, upon my word; ha, ha, ha, truly ridiculous. It is beyond a doubt, that this good old gentleman ſuppoſed me a candidate for the vacant place in this elegant manſion! Surely it ſhould teach me a leſſon; for, if purſuits, far from being reprehenſible, and a purpoſe that indiſputably wears the garb of virtue, cannot ſhield from injurious ſuſpicion, how are the votaries of folly expoſed to the multiplied ſhafts of cenſure! Unhappy ſex! whoſe ways are environed with peril; ſurely we ſhould not fail hourly to invoke the guardian care of attending angels.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Here, Madam, here they are—exactly one thouſand pounds; and you have only to ſign this bond, and the buſineſs is finiſhed.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Sir, the facility with which you have complied with my wiſhes, and your confidence in my honour, hath made me eternally your debtor.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: O! it is a mere bagatelle; never mention it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Aſſure yourſelf, Sir, that I ſhall be punctual; ſome affairs of great urgency have impelled the application of this morning.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: It matters not, Madam; I make no inquiries—life is always ſubject to viciſſitudes! and, to ſay truth, I have myſelf been lately thrown from the equality of diſpoſition that I am accuſtomed to preſerve.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Really! I truſt no accident hath happened in your family, Mr. Maitland.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, an accident of the greateſt poſſible magnitude!

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: May I aſk of what nature, Sir.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: My ſon, Madam, my only ſon, hath thought proper to fall irretrievably (as he ſays) in love with one Eliza Clairville.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: And is this the accident which hath ſo diſturbed you?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: It is, Madam.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: What is there in it ſo ſtrange?

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Excuſe me, Sir, if I expreſs my wonder at your regarding this event as a misfortune.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Why, ought I not to regard it as a misfortune, Madam?

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: I think not, Sir—Eliza Clairville poſſeſſes more dignity of ſentiment than any young perſon I have met with; ſhe is a high ſoul'd girl, and has more of mind than commonly falls to the lot of mortality.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: It may be ſo; but I hate all extremes; and I had rather ſhe were leſs aſpiring.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: I wiſh ſhe would ceaſe to play off her light airs on my boy.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Sir, a ſenſe of obligation ought, perhaps, to ſeal my lips; but, thus urged, I muſt ſay you do Miſs Clairville much wrong; and I take a particular pleaſure in repeating that ſhe is the moſt faultleſs young lady within my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, how long have you known her?

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p:
Years, Sir—ever ſince ſhe has been in the country; the lady, under whoſe protection ſhe left
France, yielded her reluctantly to my care; and, regarding her as a model of diſcretion, I beſtowed her upon my niece, on her marriage with George Bloomville.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: And how long has my hopeful ſon been enliſted in her ſervice?

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Your ſon, Sir, was early captivated by the charms of Miſs Clairville; nor ſhould you have wanted the fulleſt and moſt timely intelligence of this event, had there exiſted the ſmalleſt probability of a union of the parties.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: I do not underſtand you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Sir, I pledge my honour, my life, my reputation, that you ſhall never be entitled to call Eliza Clairville daughter, but by your unbiaſſed and avowed choice.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Very well, very well; this looks well; the young woman may be prudent; and if ſhe behaves properly, ſhe will merit my thanks.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Sir, my viſit has been unexpectedly prolonged: I wiſh you a good morning.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: I will attend you to your carriage, Madam.

div.head: VIRTUE TRIUMPHANT, continued. ACT SECOND.
div.stage: SCENE—A beautiful Garden, adjoining to Major Bloomville's Houſe.
[Eliza Clairville, ſeated in an alcove, penſively ſings:]

lg.l: AH me! what ills encompaſs round,
How thick the ſhafts of ſorrow fly;
Of hapleſs 〈◊〉 , how deep the wound,
How pangful the corroding ſigh!
An angel, in diſcretion's form,
The orphan'd maiden ſhould attend;
To ſhield her from the gathering ſtorm,
With faithful vigils ſhould deſcend.
Oh! if Eliza's plaints could woo
The ſeraph from the bending ſkies,
Then might her feeble ſteps purſue
That ſmooth ſhorn path which peace ſupplies.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: No, it will not be—muſic has not charms ſufficient to remove the melancholy preſſure by which I am borne down. Unhappy girl! orphanaged in my dawn of being—thrown on the compaſſion of ſtrangers—rendered, by the malice of my fate, an outcaſt from that compaſſion—exiled in a foreign land—involved in a hopeleſs paſſion—every ſentiment of my ſoul approving him, whom virtue impels me to reject! Wretched, wretched Eliza! ill-fated maiden! it is only from the icy darts of death thou canſt expect relief!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Madam, forgive this intruſion; I ſought you in the houſe; your ſervant informed me you were here; and having buſineſs of importance to myſelf, I ſo far preſumed on your indulgence as to follow you.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: The viſits of my friends, Mr. Maitland, can never be unwelcome.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: How cutting is this indifference! [Aſide.] Perhaps, Madam, I ought to eſteem myſelf happy, that I am admitted in the number of your friends; and yet, Miſs Clairville, to purchaſe a dearer title, had I worlds to beſtow, I would think them well relinquiſhed!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p:
It is matter of regret to me, Sir, that inſtead of that ſentimental intercourſe, which it would be one of my felicities to cultivate, you ſhould thus ſnatch every
opportunity of reference to a ſubject, which ought never to have been introduced.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ought never to have been introduced, Madam! Can, then, the rational Eliza think ſo ſeverely of that tender connexion, which hath received the ſanction of all ages, and which is the ſource of every felicity?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: No, Sir; Eliza Clairville does not think ſeverely of wedded amity; ſhe reſpects, as ſhe ought, the ſacred ties of mutual love; but when fate interpoſes its inſurmountable bars, it ſurely muſt be conſidered as the height of folly, to be thus unceaſingly at odds with deſtiny.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah! Eliza, did you but know the daggers which your words convey, you would exerciſe more lenity. Once more I ſolemnly proteſt, that, to call you mine, no ſacrifices would be deemed too great! with you, each ſpot would ſeem a paradiſe! without you, life remains a barren wilderneſs.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Sir, this is too much; your looks too abſolutely border on frenzy! If you perſiſt in what I can ſcarce forbear to term an ungenerous perſecution, I muſt, however reluctantly, requeſt Mrs. Bloomville to deny me to your viſits.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, you may ſpare that requeſt. I have called on you this morning to make one laſt effort; the ſucceſs of this effort I have already ſeen; and, with to-morrow's ſun, I bid you, perhaps, an everlaſting adieu!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: How, Cha—Mr. Maitland—What can you mean?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Simply this, Madam. Traverſing the Mall this morning with a friend, of whoſe worth, while in New-York, I had repeated proofs, we accidentally diſcovered that, added to the ties of amity, we were alſo kindred of the melancholy mood. Allied by misfortune, we have agreed to become companions in exile; and, with the coming day, I depart from thoſe native haunts, which my Eliza—forgive the freedom of a deſpairing youth—can alone teach me to value!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Are you ſerious, Sir?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Certainly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Have you the approbation of your father?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: My father will ſuppoſe me on a tour of buſineſs. [Eliza, much diſordered, melts into tears.] Good Heaven! Miſs Clairville, what mean theſe tears? Surely, the purple ſtream that warms me to exiſtence, is not ſo precious in my eſtimation. Oh! could I flatter myſelf, that tenderneſs for me impelled the kindly guſh—But no—it is impoſſible—Eliza, in what have I offended?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Mr. Maitland, your unimpeached veracity forbids me to queſtion your ſincerity—You certainly leave town to-morrow?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Undoubtedly; unleſs I ſhould be ſo ſuperlatively bleſt, as to be honoured by a countermand from you.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: In ſuch a moment as this, then, virtue herſelf will permit a degree of relaxation. You have often, Mr. Maitland, accuſed me of inſenſibility: Alas! you little knew the heart you thus arraigned; it was caſt in the mould of tenderneſs, and its deareſt ſentiments have ever been the offspring of friendſhip and of love.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: But theſe bleſt ſentiments refuſed to ſanction the vows of Maitland!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: I will be very explicit, Sir. Had I been addreſſed by a man, whom my heart and my judgment had approved, and who had been born the equal of my humble family and lowly fortunes, to a ſingle moment's ſuſpenſe he ſhould not have been condemned; my extended hand, accompanying my yielding heart, our mutual attachment ſhould have received the ſanction of the holy prieſt; and it would have become my ſtudy, to ameliorate the intereſt I had obtained in his boſom.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Charming, inimitable woman! I would have died to have originated an affection ſo divine!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p:
Ah! Charles, is it poſſible you have yet to learn, that you are indeed the friend of my choice—that my tendereſt wiſhes are your's? Nor will I bluſh
to own, that if propriety and virtue would permit, this hand ſhould be only your's.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.stage: [Seizing her hand, and bowing upon it.]
sp.p: Heavens and earth! What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: You hear a truth, Sir, which, had not inſurmountable obſtacles have oppoſed our union, ſhould long ſince have been familiar to your ear—You hear a truth, for which my breaſt ſhould ſtill have been a grave, had not the precipitancy of your departure extorted it from me: But the knowledge that we are to meet no more, hath produced, by way of juſtice to my feelings, a declaration, which ſincerity hath a thouſand times ſuggeſted. And now, Charles, may eternal bleſſings crown your virtues—receive my laſt adieu!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: What means my angel?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: That, as you depart on the morrow, a moment like this may not again preſent.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: And think you, dear, enchanting girl, that, ſo unexpectedly attaining the ſummit of felicity, I will thus voluntarily relinquiſh my ſtand?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Surely, Charles Maitland will not deceive me?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: My projected baniſhment was on the agonizing preſumption, that Eliza never could be mine.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: And it is as true, as that her each pulſation beats for thee, that ſhe never can be thine.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: You deal in paradoxes, my love!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: My meaning muſt ſurely be obvious: Eliza Clairville will never unite herſelf to a man, whoſe family deteſts her.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Let us hope that my father may be propitiated.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: That hope is not the offspring of probability; it may ſerve to illumine the pages of a novel, or produce a happy denoeument to the fifth act of a play; but as it conſiſts not with reaſon, let us not indulge it. No, my friend, proſecute your intended plan, and tender remembrance ſhall be dear to our boſoms! in dreams we will converſe, and in future worlds we ſhall be happy! Once more, adieu!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Diſtraction! a moment ſtop, if you would not reduce me to a ſtate of deſperation!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: What I can ſtill urge to ſoothe your wounded ſpirit, I will not withhold; and, in the ſame moment that I declare, I never, but on equal terms, will plight my faith with your's, I pledge to you my veracity, that this heart ſhall never know a ſecond lord—that this hand ſhall never be given but to you.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Heavenly condeſcenſion! Matchleſs goodneſs! I am in a delirium of joy!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Leave me, Charles; I entreat you to leave me; and remember, I expect the performance of your journey!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: And ſhall we, then, meet no more?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: On this one condition—that, with to-morrow's ſun, you accompany your friend.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Divine, yet ſevere arbitreſs, I obey—the mingling emotions of my boſom, it is not in language to expreſs. May guardian ſeraphs hover round you!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.stage: [After ſtanding a moment in an attitude of reflection.]
sp.p: I am not ſure I have acted quite right—the trial was unexpected, and more than proportioned to my diſcretion: But even repentance cannot recal the paſt; and, having enough of preſent miſery, I will ceaſe to arraign, or to inveſtigate.

div.stage: SCENE—An Apartment in Major Bloomville's Houſe—Books and Papers promiſcuouſly thrown about.

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: Madam, thoſe mere bagatelles, on which the cenſorious world is pleaſed to comment ſo ſeverely, would be placed by me, to the account of youth, a conſciouſneſs of ſuperior beauty, and extreme inexperience, were I ſure ſhe regarded me with that decided preference, which a huſband has a right to expect.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Bleſs me, nephew! you terrify me! Have you any doubts of her fidelity?

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: No, Madam, not abſolutely. Auguſta Bloomville has too much pride to ſubmit to actual debaſement; yet, give me leave to obſerve, that, bred in the ſchool of honour, I have imbibed a ſoldier's delicacy, and I am ready to ſay, "Ceſar's wife ſhould not be ſuſpected."

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: I have, indeed, grieved to find my niece ſo little domeſticated, and ſo regardleſs of your intereſt; but I had flattered myſelf, that the innate rectitude of her mind had rendered her conduct, in other reſpects, irreproachable.

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: Far be it from me, Madam, to accuſe my Auguſta; and yet, to you, her more than parent, it may not be wrong to ſay, that I live in a ſtate of married ſolitude! that my Auguſta, all charming as ſhe is, conſtitutes to me, a ſource of agonized inquietude! Shop-hunting, viſiting, cards, balls; theſe make up the routine of her life; while her huſband can ſcarce obtain the ſmalleſt attention!

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Strange, ſtrange degeneracy!!!

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: Every powder'd puppy has her ſmile—that coxcomical wretch—that Flaſhet, is at this moment gallanting her through the ſtreets, and eſcorting her to the new milliner's, Mrs. Lacewell's, where ſhe will doubtleſs empty her pocket-book.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Have you made her acquainted with your late embarraſſments?

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: I have not; for, notwithſtanding her unkindneſs, I cannot, for my ſoul, bring myſelf to inflict on her a ſingle moment's unneceſſary pain.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Your indulgence merits a reward; and a thorough knowledge of the principles of my niece authorizes me to ſay, that time will remove your difficulties.

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: Heaven grant it.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Amen. I have taken up for you, George, one thouſand pounds, of which I think you ſaid you ſtood in immediate need.

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: You ſurpriſe me, Madam! Surely, you have not withdrawn your intereſt from the ſtocks?

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: No, George, I have not—inquire no further. Let it ſuffice, that I have deranged no plans, and that I have procured the money on common intereſt.

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: Ever ſince the moment which introduced me to the knowledge of Matronia, ſhe hath continued uniformly and condeſcendingly kind, and my obligations are unreturnable.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: You eſtimate common actions too highly. Here are the bills; and if they may contribute to your convenience, my reward will be more than proportioned to my merit!

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: They will do me incalculable ſervice, Madam; and I will go this moment and adjuſt a buſineſs, in which my commercial reputation is importantly involved.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: And I will await the return of my niece in her dreſſing-room.

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: Incomparable woman! If ſhe ſucceeds in ſhaping the conduct of her niece after the model of her own exalted character, my happineſs will be complete. Here, William—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Did you call, Sir?

sp.speaker: Major B.
sp.p: Yes, William; take care of theſe books and papers; and, if I am inquired for at dinner, let your miſtreſs know, I ſhall not return until the evening.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: My miſtreſs! um, um, um! ſhe will hardly make the inquiry, I believe.

sp.speaker: Deb.
sp.p: Here, you fellows, William, John, Thomas, Molly! Why, where the dickens are you all? You Sir, why do you loiter thus, pray?

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p:
I wonders who calls—ſo I does—one would think the houſe was on fire—I never was in ſuch a place in all my born days—ſo many miſtreſſes—
• 'fackins! I wiſhes I was at home, milking my cows again—ſo I does.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Zookers! Molly, don't ſpeak ſo loud; for if you do, Mrs. Deborah will hear you, as ſure as eggs is bacon.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: And who cares if ſhe does? [contemptuouſly.]

sp.speaker: Deb.
sp.p: Why, what the plague are you muttering about, there? Did you expect to come into ſuch a houſe as this, to ſit on the cupboard's head? Only ſee now, what a litter is here! Do you not know, there are ladies calling every hour in the morning?—rap, rap, rap—no peace for the knocker. Here, you dainty fingers, clear theſe meſſage-boards, that we may have room for freſh cards; and you, William, do you pick up theſe books and papers, and ſee that the ſteps and ſtreet before the door are thoroughly ſwept and cleanſed.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Pray now, good Miſtreſs Deborah, what is all this buſtle about? Why need you put yourſelf in ſuch a wicked paſſion?

sp.speaker: Deb.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, ſaucy jackanapes. Do you not know, that there are ſtrangers expected at dinner, and company in the afternoon? Stir your ſtumps, I ſay; ſtir your ſtumps, all of you.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: I'm reſolv'd I gives Madam warning before to-morrow night—getting up by break of day in the morning, ſitting up till midnight, cleaning here, and running there—one has not a moment's quiet—and I gets nothing by it after all, only four dirty ſhillings a week, while Mrs. Gadabout's Suſan has a whole dollar, only for dreſſing her miſtreſs's falſe hair.

sp.speaker: Deb.
sp.p: Let's have none of your ſauce, Mrs. Minx. Marry come up! Do you not know, 'tis an honour to ſerve Mrs. Bloomville? But while I am ſpending my time to talk to you, my cakes and tarts will be burnt to cinder; ſo you had beſt mind your buſineſs, and get the room in order as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: I'll not ſtay here—ſo I won't.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Pſhaw, pſhaw! good Molly, never mind it, never mind it. Why, I'll be hang'd now, if I don't think Miſtreſs Deborah was born ſcolding; and what is bred in the bone will never come through the ſkin, as the ſaying is.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Why, William, it would provoke a miniſter—ſo it would.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I tell you what, Molly, I have been thinking and thinking, and I do now really believe, as ſure as we are born, Molly, that this Miſtreſs Deborah of our's, is the Witch of Endor.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: That ſhe is, Mr. William; and ſo, as every good Chriſtian ſhould, I hates all witches and witchgoblins, as bad as I hates Old Nick.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ah! that's right, Molly, that's right—But we muſt make haſte now, and do our work, or ſhe, being a witch, will ſartingly bewitch us, and haunt us into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Deb.
sp.p: Here you, Molly, William! Where the plague are you both?

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Let me die if ſhe ben't calling again. Well, I knows I'll quit this ſervice before it be very long.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I follows Molly—butter me if I don't.

div.stage: SCENE—Another Apartment in Mr. Bloomville's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: It is in vain I ſhift the ſcene! the ſettled gloom on my ſpirit knows no abatement!

div.stage: [Enter Miſs Dorinda Scornwell, ſans ceremonie, and with a ſupercilious air.]

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Is your lady viſible today, child?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Madam Bloomville is in her dreſſing-room, Miſs Scornwell.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, young woman? you look diſturb'd.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, I am perfectly tranquil.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Well, girl, will you trip to your lady, and let her know, Miſs Dorinda Scornwell has done herſelf the honour of calling on her this morning.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: You ſhall be obeyed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Creature! ſhe abſolutely apes the grace and dignity of we people of faſhion. I hate your dirt-ſprung beings. If this Bloomville was a degree removed from idiotiſm, ſhe would long ſince have diſcarded her, eſpecially as I have ſo often remonſtrated on this head.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Madam, my miſtreſs requeſts your company in her dreſſing-room.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: I attend her, William.

div.stage: [Matronia and Mrs. Bloomville ſeated—Miſs Dorinda Scornwell enters—both ladies riſe and courteſy.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Dear Dorinda, I am monſtrouſly happy to ſee you! I called at your lodgings en paſſant, in the courſe of a tour I have been making among the ſhops, and was mortified to death at not finding you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: You are a charming creature, it muſt be confeſſed: But it is a divine morning; and I have already looked in on a little hundred of my friends. It is true, I was happy enough to find many of them had rambled abroad; but my call will, nevertheleſs, anſwer every purpoſe quite as well.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Really, Miſs Scornwell! this is quite a new method of calculation; it is the firſt time I have ever heard the abſence of friends placed in the chapter of felicities!

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: O Madam! we do theſe things every day—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.p: Niece—I had communications for your private ear; but as you are at preſent engaged, and I have viſits of friendſhip to make, I will call on you a few hours hence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: I ſhall expect you with pleaſure, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: I ſuſpect, Auguſta, that my preſence is ill timed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Your preſence, my friend, can never be ill timed.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Thank you, Bloomville. I have had a fatiguing round this morning—the people in this town will never learn breeding—New-York is more than a century advanced before us!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: It is really ſurpriſing!

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: We are tormented to death by ſtiff compliments, and all the awkward grimace of ceremony! Heaven haſten the reign of true politeneſs, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Dear Dorinda, I ſecond your petition with genuine ardour; for I am a perfect enthuſiaſt in my admiration of thoſe eaſy manners, which are always the appendage of real gentility.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: And then, forſooth! there is an affectation of ſentiment, which is altogether intolerable: "I ſuppoſe, Miſs Scornwell, [ſpeaks affectedly] you was preſent at the repreſentation of the Jew—Is it not a ſweet play?—The Jew was a noble fellow, and Eliza Ratcliff was a moſt intereſting girl—it was replete with ſentiment, and both myſelf and daughters were drown'd in tears."

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: You muſt own, however, that theſe remarks are not very ill placed.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Why, to tell you the truth, Bloomville, I am not extravagantly pleaſed with theſe ſame ſentiments—I prefer cards to converſation, a ride to a book, and the ball-room to the play-houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Not a ſtrong predilection in favour of ſentiment, Miſs Scornwell! amazing! Why, ſooner than I would confeſs myſelf at odds with ſentiment, I would relinquiſh all pretenſions to taſte, quarrel with benevolence for its benignity, with the ſun for its brightneſs, and with Philenia for the captivating charms of her underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p:
Well, well—I am not deſirous of quarreling with Auguſta for any thing. I was laſt night at
the aſſembly, where, if I had not expired at the thought of your abſence, I ſhould have been the happieſt being in the univerſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Yes, indeed; for at the very moment when I was on the point of ſecuring my number, who ſhould enter the ball-room, but the very enamorata that I met at the New-York aſſemblies; drawn thither, undoubtedly, by my irreſiſtible ladyſhip, and evidently improved in every faſcinating grace!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: This was indeed fortunate.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Fortunate! it threw me into the moſt happy flow of ſpirits imaginable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Did chance give him to you for a partner.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: The Colonel never dances—ſo we enjoyed a moſt enchanting aſide converſation, cut in at whiſt, came off victorious in the rubbers, and thus concluded a divine evening.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Why will you not indulge me with the name of your redoubtable hero?

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Becauſe I mean to preſent you with the name and perſon of my Adonis in the ſame moment; and, by the way, he hath engaged to eſcort me to your levee this very afternoon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: I ſhall be happy to ſee him, undoubtedly. Pray, what figure did our ladies make before this ſtranger?

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: O the frights! but he had eyes only for me. There was Mrs. Gadabout, moſt prepoſterouſly dreſſed, and Miſs Trimwell, loaded with finery, while Betty Brilliant ſeemed a moving jeweller's ſhop.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! O Scornwell! you are monſtrouſly ſevere.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: There, too, was that antiquated dame, Arabella Worthy, whoſe face is a perfect antidote to every idea of conviviality; not a female but ſeems to ſhun her; and yet, becauſe, forſooth! ſhe chooſes to commence Argus to her baby-faced daughter, ſhe never miſſes an aſſembly! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Such outree heads—ſuch a redundancy of ſilks, laces, ribbons and feathers—O it is ridiculous! truly ridiculous, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Dear Dorinda, you have given me as perfect an idea of them as if I had myſelf been preſent.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: O! by the bye—Do you know that I abſolutely ſaw Tom Dapperwit and Miſs Lovett, paſs, arm under arm, down the covered promenade laſt evening? that off down to the ground, eyes rivetted, and tongue as ſmooth as oil.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? I had thought that affair was entirely given up.

sp.speaker: Miſs. Sc.
sp.p: O! ſhe is the very quinteſſence of prudery—But now I think of it, I promiſed to accompany her this morning, on a viſit to Mrs. Arabella Worthy, and I make it a point not to break my word.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Well, dear, Dorinda, I ſhall expect you at tea, accompanied by your agreeable Colonel. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Adieu. Ma chere amie.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: This chere amie of mine, is wholly abſorbed in what ſhe terms pleaſure—I, too, have made the experiment; I have plunged into a life of gaiety, and the concluſion, which forces itſelf upon me, does not decide in favour of diſſipation. Would, that fate had given me an object in which I could take an intereſt!—But I muſt not indulge reflections of this nature—it ſhall not be long before I will ſet about a reformation; and, by way of exordium, as I have a few leiſure moments, I will devote them to Miſs Clairville.
Requeſt Miſs Clairville to favour me with her company.

sp.speaker: Molly.
sp.p: Yes, an't pleaſe your La'ſhip.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: I have too much neglected the good Eliza of late: There is a kind of dignity and uniform propriety in her deportment, which involves a tacit cenſure upon the whim and levity of my more ſplendid acquaintance.
Miſs Clairville, we have, for many weeks, been much eſtranged; permit me, my dear, to aſſure you, that this circumſtance does not contribute to my felicity.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: You do me honour, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Madam! Why that formal appellation? Let me be known as your Auguſta; and addreſs me as in thoſe happy days, when order led the hours, and my aunt preſided our ſweetly indulgent monitreſs.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: It was, indeed, a bliſsful period.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Why that ſigh, Eliza? that ſwelling boſom, and that falling tear? Give me leave to tell you, that I have ſtill a heart to feel for the ſorrows of my Eliza.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: You are too good, Auguſta. My ſorrows ſhould be all my own, while happineſs remains for Mrs. Bloomville.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Fie! fie! Eliza, do not let deſpair, with blighting influence, blaſt your opening proſpects. I ſhall yet ſee you bleſt in your own way—the amiable and deſerving wife of Maitland.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Never, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Why not? Is he not truly worthy?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: O! he is all luxuriant fancy can image, mid its golden dreams of happineſs—In figure, unexceptionable—in grace, inimitable—in mind, the model of perfection—firm as integrity—melting with ſympathy for every child of woe—manly and brave, as conſcious worth can render him—mild as the gentle breath of zephyr—candid as mercy—open as the liberal hand of Heaven—and frank as young ſincerity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: O brave! It is evident, however, that his picture is drawn by the laviſh pencil of his miſtreſs; but, do you know that this ſame idol of your's was once on the very point of devoting himſelf to me; and that your ſaucy face, very mal-apropos, preſented itſelf to rob me of my conqueſt? However, be not alarmed, child, I am not vindictive; and I ſhall give my voice for a ſpeedy wedding.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: I ſhall never be the wife of Charles Maitland, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: What is to hinder, in the name of goodneſs?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: I will never obtrude myſelf on a worthy family, which would juſtly conſider me as an obſtacle to their advancement.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: We will find means to conciliate the elder Mr. Maitland.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Were he to condeſcend to woo me for his daughter, I would perſiſt in my rejection.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Strange romantic girl!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Madam, in vindication of this, my unalterable determination, I will furniſh you with ſome particulars relative to myſelf, which I have not, till now, thought it neceſſary to divulge.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: I am all attention.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: I drew my firſt breath in humble life—my parents commending me to the care of an opulent and noble family in England, left me an infant orphan; and my only patrimony was their benediction. From the family in which I was thrown, I received an education which might have ſuited royalty; but ere I had completed my fifteenth year, my patroneſs, the firſt of women, ſwelled her laſt ſigh! Forgive my tears; the unexampled goodneſs of my loſt benefactreſs, muſt ever excite them; they are a tribute due to her ineſtimable worth!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Your tears are natural, and I cordially ſympathize with you.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p:
My happineſs fled with my angel protectreſs; the family eſtates devolved on the youngeſt ſon, who, of a numerous progeny, alone ſurvived: This gentleman was a bachelor, and many years my ſenior; the ill ſtate of health under which he at that time laboured, with the immoderate grief occaſioned by the death of his excellent mother, who had long been his only parent, induced his phyſicians to adviſe a reſidence of ſome months in the ſouth of France, and it was judged neceſſary I ſhould accompany him. What ſhall I ſay—a ſenſe of gratitude and honour ſeems to tie
my tongue, and the ſhade of my departed benefactreſs arbitrarily impoſes ſilence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Without being a conjurer, I can eaſily decypher the conſequences; your quondam guardian was metamorphoſed into a lover.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: I imagined him a bright exemplar of every virtue; but, forgetful of the ties of honour and the delicacy of my ſituation, he was capable of forming a deliberate ſcheme of ſeduction! and, while he aſſumed the guiſe of a tenderneſs truly paternal, he was cruelly plotting my ruin!!!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: O Lord! I almoſt gaſp for you! By what means did you receive the knowledge of his infamous deſigns?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: From a faithful friend, who, like a guardian ſeraph, hovered round my ſteps, and procured me a ſight of letters, written by his own hand, wherein the deep laid ſcheme was fully arranged!!!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Theſe, indeed, were indiſputable evidences. How did you eſcape?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: The proofs, as you obſerve, were irrefragable; and, when he commenced his plan of operation, by inviting me to a little tour, in the progreſs of which, he engaged to make me certain communications which would importantly involve my future proſpects, my vigilant friend received me to her arms, and ſecretly procured me a rank in the family of that lady, then on the eve of her departure from France, with whom your excellent aunt firſt ſaw me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Your hiſtory, Eliza, is indeed eventful; but for my ſoul I cannot ſee a ſingle circumſtance which reaſon can conſider as a bar to your union with Maitland.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Surely, Madam, you muſt have ſeen that I am lowly born, portionleſs and unfriended! and ſhall I come like a heavy cloud on the proſpects of that good young man! a ſtep ſo reprehenſible, would indeed evince me unwarrantably intereſted; nor will I enter a family whoſe every attention I ſhould regard as a condeſcenſion which would tinge my cheek with the hectic of conſcious inferiority.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Do you not perceive, Eliza, that it is hardly conſiſtent with your flighty ſentiments, to ſet ſuch a prodigious value on money?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: I do but ſubmit to a neceſſity which the deſpot, Cuſtom, hath rendered irreverſible; and beſides, Madam, who that hath experienced the luxury of wiping the tear from the haggard cheek of penury, will deny, I had almoſt ſaid, the omnipotence of money!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Well, well, I will only ſay that you are a dear, irreſiſtible, romantic girl: But, as the dinner bell rings, we muſt haſte to meet our gueſts, and we will ſeize the firſt opportunity of converſing further on theſe momentous affairs.

div.head: VIRTUE TRIUMPHANT, continued. ACT THIRD.
div.stage: SCENE—An Apartment in Mr. Maitland's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: DEAR heart! dear heart! theſe old eyes are almoſt blind with weeping! and my grey hairs, I verily think, will be brought with ſorrow to the grave!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Good Robert, be comforted.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Alas! Sir! how can I be comforted? There is no good got by wandering from home. Maſter Charles, a young man, as you are, can have no idea of the miſchiefs which abound in this wicked world!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: You ſeem to have forgot thoſe principles which ſhould ſupport your age; you ſhould remember that I ſhall have the ſame protection in diſtant lands that has been my refuge in America.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: This is very true, Sir, but— [ſighs deeply.]

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: But what, Robert?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: But theſe are perilous times, Sir; very perilous times; it looks as if there would not be a mother's ſon left in the Old World; and, when I conſider how often I have carried you in theſe arms, it afflicts me ſorely, Maſter Charles, that you ſhould run after wars, and murders, and bloodſhed.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I am not going to the field of battle, Robert.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: There is no knowing what may take place, Sir; and then this Colonel Mellfont belongs to the Engliſh—every body ſays they will have bloody times in England, Maſter Charles; and, for my part, Sir, I think them are beſt off who have leaſt to do either with French or Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Robert, theſe prejudices are unworthy of your benevolence.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Well, may be ſo, may be ſo; but my heart ſtrangely miſgives me; and if you go, poor Robert will have ſeen you for the laſt time! and who is there left to pity or to care for me!!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: My father will take care of you, Robert.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, Maſter is very good; but—but— [weeps.]

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Poor old man! I do not like to ſee thee weep. Haſt thou viſited our friends in Stricken Alley, as I requeſted?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Oh! Sir! could you have heard their piteous lamentations, I am ſure it would have melted you!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Lamentations, Robert?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; for at the ſame time that I gave them your liberal benefaction, I informed them of your intended departure; and ſuch a general ſhout of ſorrow, old as I am, I never before heard.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Poor unfortunates!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: And then ſuch bleſſings as they poured on you—His reward will be great, ſaid one—It cannot exceed his deſervings, ſaid another—May the good God protect him, ſaid all.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I feel myſelf enriched by their united benedictions.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: But what, dear Sir, will become of them?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: They ſhall ſtill be my care.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: But who will take care of Madam Eliza, Sir?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: What do you mean, Robert?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Excuſe me, Sir, but, in my humble opinion, there never was a more heavenly minded young lady; and I have ſaid it a thouſand and a thouſand times, that ſhe was the exact reſemblance of my young Maſter.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Of me?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; for whenever I have carried her your letters, ſhe has been ſo gracious, and has inquired ſo kind after my little orphan grand-children!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Miſs Clairville is indeed an angel.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: And, when I have ventured to ſpeak of your charities, Sir—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Of my charities?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; how you took the poor man out of priſon; purchaſed all his goods at auction; and, after reſtoring both them and him to his wife and children, how you gave him a ſum of money to begin buſineſs again: How you were conſtantly taking the part of the oppreſſed. When I have told her all theſe things, and much more, Sir, ſhe would turn away to wipe off the tears, and then, lifting up her white hands and beautiful blue eyes to heaven, Robert, ſays ſhe, your Maſter is a good young man, and a bleſſing will ſurely attend him.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Was my Eliza ſo kind?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: O yes, Sir, I cannot remember the half of what I have heard her ſay; but we all think, if once you come together, there will not be a poor perſon within a hundred miles of your dwelling.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Well, Robert, we muſt all ſubmit to neceſſity. Go, my good fellow, and deſire Mr. Weſton to ſtep hither.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I will go, Sir.—It breaks my heart to think of his turning out into the world in theſe bad times.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Poor old man! I am not aſhamed to own that the parting with him is not the leaſt of my inquietudes. But my Eliza, exalted pattern of every excellence! may Heaven ſhield thy virtues: Surely the gifts of fortune are eſtimated at the very loweſt rate, when they are withheld from merit ſo tranſcendent, and profuſely ſhowered on vice and folly.
Well, Weſton, what ſays my father?

sp.speaker: Weſton.
sp.p: He takes the matter preciſely as you expected; he thinks your abſence will be temporary; laughs at the idea of your perpetual baniſhment; and pleaſes himſelf with anticipating your victory over a paſſion which he pronounces extravagant, the mere conſequence of youth and inexperience: And he doubts not, he ſhall ſee you in the full enjoyment of that happy calm which is the offspring of reaſon, and the corrected ſucceſſor of the heyday of the blood.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: A mere duplicate of what he ſaid to me not an hour ſince.—I have narrated to you my eclairciſſement with Miſs Clairville.

sp.speaker: Weſton.
sp.p: That eclairciſſement muſt have been very ſatisfactory.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why, Weſton, ſo it was; and yet, ſtrange as it may ſeem, while the recollection of her tenderneſs elevates me above myſelf, a recurrence to her determined reſolution ſpreads over my ſoul a kind of melancholy calm, which very much reſembles deſpair.

sp.speaker: Weſton.
sp.p: But ought you not rather to implant hope thereon, or at leaſt to forego your deſign of quitting us?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: To what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Weſton.
sp.p: Methinks flight implies cowardice, while the exerciſe of manly firmneſs might reſtore your peace; and, it ſhould be remembered, that we ought to ſuſtain rather than quit our poſts.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I do not ſee that my removal from hence is quitting my poſt.

sp.speaker: Weſton.
sp.p: You ſeem ſtationed here by Providence; it is your native place, and your munificence has rendered you a general bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: It is not my intention to elude the deſigns of Providence; I will purſue commerce, and if my father's overgrown fortunes ſhould come into my poſſeſſion, I will deviſe a regular ſyſtem, which ſhall render them as uſeful as their magnitude will admit.

sp.speaker: Weſton.
sp.p: Excellent young man! ſurely the interpoſition of Heaven will be manifeſted in your favour!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: There is little merit in beſtowing on the neceſſities of others what we cannot poſſibly appropriate to our own emolument. Have you adjuſted thoſe accounts which I committed to your care?

sp.speaker: Weſton.
sp.p: I have carefully executed your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Are the receipts paſt?

sp.speaker: Weſton.
sp.p: They are, Sir.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Then there remains but one account open; Major Bloomville is conſiderably in arrears to me, but as I have reaſon to think his circumſtances a little deranged, I will not make application to him.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Sir, the Engliſh Colonel deſires to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Show him in, by all means.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: O, lack a day! lack a day!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: The deep grief, of which this fellow's countenance is expreſſive, really affects me.

sp.speaker: Weſton.
sp.p: It muſt indeed intereſt your humanity; but I will now devote myſelf to thoſe preparations which yet remain to be made previous to your departure.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Do, Mr. Weſton.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Mr. Maitland, your moſt obedient—I have called on you to learn if you held your purpoſe, relative to your journey; but I could hardly perſuade your ſervant to permit my entrance.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p:
He is a weak old man; and, much concerned at the proſpect of my departure, he has, perhaps,
conceived a kind of prejudice againſt the perſon, to whom he imputes a deſign, which he imagines ſo ill adviſed. There is ſome allowance due to years, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Undoubtedly. Poor fellow, I would gladly dry his tears—I always feel compaſſion for perſons in a ſtate of ſervitude and dependence, Mr. Maitland.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: You are perfectly right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Mr. Maitland, has an added claim to my attention; old age, and grief, are powerful recommendations to that heart, which hath been long a proficient in the ſchool of affliction.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I have often been fearful that your boſom harboured ſome latent cauſe of grief; and our laſt converſation, without explaining the nature of your misfortunes, has confirmed my ſuſpicions, given me a very important intereſt in your happineſs, and originated a wiſh that I could be any how inſtrumental in producing it.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: You are truly friendly; but, as the knowledge of my misfortunes can be of no immediate import, it may ſuffice to ſay that I am unhappy; that I wander from place to place without diminiſhing my ſorrow, and that I hardly expect a remedy this ſide the grave.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir; I can commiſerate, without being impertinent.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Nay, the probability is, that the accuſation of impertinence will devolve upon me; for, I am induced to put a queſtion, which only a long and approved friendſhip can juſtify. I am informed, that you quit this town with a declaration that you will never return to it again! and that you are driven hence by unſucceſsful love! Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: It is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Methinks, Mr. Maitland, the lady muſt have made an erroneous calculation, who refuſes to exchange her vows with your's.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p:
You are very polite, Sir; but mine is no uncommon caſe. Fortune, blind to the perfections of
the moſt charming and accompliſhed of women, ſat her down in her book of diſtributions, pennyleſs.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Does your father approve of your attachment?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: By no means; he condemns it as the groſſeſt abſurdity.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: But how happens it that he has no eyes for merit ſo conſpicuous?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: My father has never yet ſeen Miſs Clairville. An exceſs of delicacy leading her to conceive that viſiting in promiſcuous company, and frequenting public places, would ill accord with her humble fortune—ſhe is only to be met in the circle of a few intimate friends, with whom my father is not converſant.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: This is unfortunate—if you could, by any means, procure an interview, youth, beauty and innocence might become very powerful pleaders.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Alas! Sir, my father will not ſee my Eliza; and, if he could even be brought to conſent to our union, it is more than probable Miſs Clairville would reject our united ſupplications; for, while ſhe has, in the moſt unequivocal terms, avowed her preference, ſhe has, with the ſame breath, declared that ſhe will never meet me at the altar, but on equal ground.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: This is noble, it muſt be confeſſed; but it is eaſier to form reſolutions than to perſiſt in them; indeed, the capability of ſuch a determination, is, in itſelf, a prodigious effort, eſpecially in a young woman. She, doubtleſs, has her adviſers—are any of her friends within my knowledge?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I think you mixed in the ſame circles with Miſs Dorinda Scornwell, while in New-York; her intimacy with the Bloomville family, gives her frequent opportunities with my Eliza.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: This may be a happy circumſtance. I will requeſt the honour of her private ear. I have often known female influence acquire an aſcendency, which demanded the utmoſt addreſs to ſurmount.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, you are about to engage in a very untoward affair.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Perhaps not. I have ſome knowledge of the character of your father—if I could converſe with him on your ſubject, I have a pre-ſentiment that I could inſpire him with a degree of complacency for my opinion.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: You would find it an Herculean labour; but I will ſtep to the library, where, at this hour, he is commonly to be found, and I dare ſay he will be with you in a moment.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Written in the irreverſible decrees of fate, the ſon of ſorrow! I would extract a balm for my lacerated boſom from every fair occaſion, in the which I can mitigate the ills, that ſeem allotted for a fellow creature: Indeed, the power to ſoothe the woe-fraught mind, partakes eſſentially the nature of divinity. O Howard! Howard! illuſtrious philanthropiſt! thou wert the verieſt mental epicure that ever mere humanity embodied.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Give me leave, Sir, to introduce to you my very worthy friend, Col. Mellfont.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Servant, Sir—ſervant.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: I am, Sir, happy in an opportunity of paying my reſpects to the parent of a young perſon, to whom my heart hath, for a conſiderable time, been not a little attached.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: I am obliged to you, Sir; but, as to happineſs, Sir, it is an extreme which may do well enough as a Utopian plant, but which has never yet been found to take a very deep root in America.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: We accuſtom ourſelves, Sir, to a language, which, although perhaps, ſtrictly ſpeaking, is not chaſte; yet, as it is generally underſtood, receives, nevertheleſs, a current acceptation.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Ah, very likely, very likely—this world is given to ſee things through a falſe medium.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p:
I am perfectly of your opinion, Sir; the world is, indeed, given to error; it is only a ſelect few who ſee things as they are; while the blinded multitude,
borne in the vortex of folly, will continue their idle whirl on the very brink of deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: That is a ſtriking ſentiment, Sir—"the blinded multitude, borne in the vortex of folly, will continue their idle whirl upon the very brink of deſtruction." I congratulate thee, Charles, on having attained ſo valuable a friend.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Sir, I have long been deeply impreſſed with a very high ſenſe of the worth of Col. Mellfont.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: You are very obliging, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Sir, you deſerve it; you have ſpoken rationally. I have always been a cool, deliberate man, Sir, a lover of reaſon, and a friend of equality: Some of my countrymen hate Frenchmen—ſome hate Engliſhmen—theſe are both extremes, Sir; but, for my part, I love a man of worth, let him be the growth of what clime he will. I am a true brother of the Royal Arch—my motto is equality, and I embrace the brotherhood with my whole heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Admirable, Mr. Maitland—truly admirable! I have often wondered at the early virtues of my friend Charles; but, as his youth has been formed under the genial influence of an example ſo tranſcendently excellent, I ſhall henceforward ceaſe to wonder.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Why, ah! Charles is well enough for a young man, as young men go—he has, perhaps, a few youthful follies that ſtand in need of pruning, and he may make a tolerable figure.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: I cannot but regret, Sir, whatever pleaſure I may anticipate from the tour, that he is ſo ſoon to be removed from your guardian obſervation.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: It is his own choice, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir, this choice may be influenced by circumſtances. I ſuppoſe, my friend, that you would prefer a father's wing, to a ſtate of wandering, amid that world of which you, at preſent, know ſo little?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir; but, ſuch is my unhappy ſituation, that thoſe ſcenes which have heretofore contributed to my felicity, now ſtand forth, mementos of the ſeverity of my deſtiny!

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Ah! let him make the experiment, Colonel—let him make the experiment—he talks of never returning; but, this is all mere romance: we ſhall ſoon ſee him again, like the prodigal ſon, cap in hand; and he will then know how to diſtinguiſh properly, and to make prudent calculations, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Sir, you are my father; I therefore owe you reverence, and I will be patient.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Patience! ah, there is not a better ingredient in life, Charles, than patience; it is the very eſſence of Moderation—cultivate patience, boy, and thou ſhalt have my bleſſing with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Spoken like a father! I dare ſay, Sir, it is your wiſh that your ſon ſhould proſecute buſineſs under your own eye.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; but, if he, not having received a ſufficient quantum of centripetal force, is thus neglectful of the laws of gravitation, thus centrifugally inclined, and chooſes to fly off in a tangent, I ſhall not conſtitute his antipodes—I ſhall not weep myſelf into a Niobe; I can tell him that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Will you permit me, Sir, as the friend of your ſon, and the admirer of yourſelf, to ſpeak with freedom?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: O Sir, I have all ſuitable regard to freedom; and it is my wiſh to ſupport liberty of ſpeech, by all means.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: In perfect confidence then, that I ſhall not offend, and with all due deference to your ſuperior judgment, I will ſay, that I do not know any event that can have a more probable tendency to eſtabliſh a young man in life, with the faireſt proſpects of tranquility, than an early connexion with a diſcreet and deſerving young woman.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, provided always, that the choice of the ſaid young woman be diſcreetly made, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: And what, Sir, in your opinion, conſtitutes a diſcreet choice?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p:
Equality, Sir; by all means, equality. If I have got ten thouſand pound, the caſe is clear, ſhe
muſt lay down ten thouſand pound; and thus it will appear a connexion of cool, deliberate prudence, and not the impaſſioned, high flying reſult of romantic folly.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: But, Sir, are there not qualities infinitely more valuable than riches?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, Sir; and if it were a law as irrevocable as that of the Medes and Perſians, that no one, who poſſeſſed money, ſhould ſuperadd merit, I would aſſuredly give my voice in favour of merit.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: You would, certainly, Mr. Maitland, find an exquiſite pleaſure in tranſplanting virtue into the moſt friendly ſoil.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Give me leave to tell you, Colonel, once for all, that I am not fond of your exquiſites—moderation is my deſideratum; and my plan is, to abide by its dictates.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: Moderation is certainly highly eſtimable, Sir.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Why, now, Col. Mellfont, in things of leſs conſequence, you would be in the exerciſe of prudence—you would not ſtake a thouſand pound, in a game of whiſt or quadrille, againſt ſix-pence, Colonel. My name is Ralph Maitland, Sir; and I am determined to act for myſelf—I have not yet got into my dotage, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: You ought, undoubtedly, Sir, to be your own maſter; and you are right, in ſuppoſing I would not hazard a thouſand pound againſt ſix-pence; and yet, Sir, I ſhould conceive, that a thouſand pound was well laid out, in purchaſing a virtue, in communicating felicity, or, in placing a fellow-creature in the rank, for which nature ſeems to have deſigned her.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p:
Ah! ah! all this is very fine talking; but virtue is not to be bought and ſold, nor, do I pretend to write notes, critical and explanatory, on the deſigns of nature; and, moreover, Colonel, you are quite wide in your calculations, for I am not ignorant of the purpoſe for which you have given yourſelf all this unneceſſary trouble; but, I ſay, you are quite wide of the
matter; it is not in my power to communicate felicity, for the young woman, being a rational young woman, is herſelf perfectly convinced, that her connexion with my ſon would, in the nature of things, be highly prepoſterous.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: This conviction muſt have proceeded from a ſweet and amiable diſpoſition; it has made me a lover of her character; did ſhe aſſure you of this herſelf, Sir?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: O, no Sir, I never ſaw her in my life.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: And do you not think it would be proper you ſhould pay her a viſit of acknowledgment on this occaſion?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Perhaps it may, Sir; and in order to convince Charles that I will comply with him in all that is reaſonable, I do not much care if I call upon the girl on this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Did you call, maſter Charles?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: No, good Robert; and I would thank you to ſee that we are not broken in upon.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I will, Sir, I will. Heaven bleſs him; I have not ſeen him look ſo happy this many a day; who knows what may happen after all! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: We ſhall be ſubject to continual interruptions here, Charles, I will therefore invite you both to my library, and we will there adjuſt the neceſſary preliminaries to this viſit of acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: Col. M.
sp.p: I will attend you with pleaſure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Sir, you have bound me to you by yet added ties.

div.stage: SCENE—The Veſtibule of Mr. Maitland's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: Here you, Mr. Grey Hairs, where is my friend Charles?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: My maſter, Sir, is very buſy, and can't be interrupted at preſent.

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: Can't be interrupted, raſcal?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Raſcal, Sir! that is a name which I never yet received from either of my maſters!

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: Don't prate, old fellow, don't prate, I ſay; or, as I am a ſoldier, I will lend thee a blow that ſhall lay thee as ſtiff as was Julius Ceſar, when he was beheaded by Oliver Cromwell. Sir, I am your maſter's friend; tell him Captain Flaſhet waits for him, and you will ſee he will preſent himſelf immediately, Sir.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what a fiery blade it is; I had beſt decamp, I believe!

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: If we men of the ſword do not exert ourſelves, and be ſeen in our places, we ſhall be treated with as little reſpect as a dead Carthagenian, and as our employment is undoubtedly honourable, even as honourable as was that of the great Charles of Conſtantinople, when he ſwore eternal enmity to the Ruſſian Scipio's, ſo I think proper to behave with dignity, and to ſhow, on all occaſions, a becoming ſpirit.
Send that grey headed old fellow to me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: Why Tantalus, when he was broil'd on the gridiron by old Father Gregory, was never worſe treated.
Well ſirrah, where is your maſter—ha?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Good Sir, be not angry with an old man! My maſter Sir, bid me to make his excuſes, and 〈◊〉 tell you that being engaged in buſineſs of importance, he could not wait on you at this time.

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: You lie, ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I—

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, you old ſcoundrel—I'll teach you what it is to affront an officer of my rank.
sp.stage: [Collars and ſhakes him furiouſly—Robert roars out.]

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: For ſhame, for ſhame, Captain! lift your hand againſt a feeble, grey headed old man!

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: Yes Sir, an old ſcoundrel who has uſed me ill.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Sir, he is not a ſcoundrel; he has acted entirely by my direction.

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: Acted by your direction, Sir?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and what have you to ſay to that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: That I am not treated like a gentleman, Sir.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Robert, you may go.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Now pray, dear maſter—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Away—you know I will be obeyed. [Exit Robert, agitated and alarmed.] If you conceive yourſelf injured, Captain Flaſhet, I will not deny you redreſs. I do not mean to violate the laws of hoſpitality in this manſion; but you will know how to call on me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: O! not in the leaſt, my dear friend, not in the leaſt! no, I perfectly coincide in opinion with the brave Tacitus, in his reply to Pope Clement—If Clement is tired of his life, he ſhall not find death on the point of my ſword: So, my very dear friend, I wiſh you a very good day.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—this is truly ridiculous—ha, ha, ha.

div.head: VIRTUE TRIUMPHANT, continued. ACT FOURTH.
div.stage: SCENE—An Apartment in Major Bloomville's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p:
HEIGH ho! Time wears but ſlowly; and yet, when I think on to-morrow's ſun, it hath an eagle's wing! Farewel! a laſt farewel!
What deep-felt pangs doth that heart-affecting word involve!!!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Miſs Eliza, there is a gentleman, Mr. Maitland, who wiſhes to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Hah! I had thought his viſit would have been delayed until evening. [Aſide.] Be ſo good as to deſire Mr. Maitland to walk in.

And now, aſſiſt me, each incentive which can render firm a feeble maiden—ſhed over me thy invigorating influence, divine fortitude—ſupport me through this laſt interview! and to tender regret, a comfortleſs victim, I thenceforward devote me!

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: An aſſemblage of all that is lovely in woman! [Aſide.] I hope I do not intrude, young lady?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: In the name of wretchedneſs, who can this be? [Aſide.] Have you any commands for me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: For thee, Madam! Thou lookeſt as if thou wert formed to give, rather than receive commands! O the rogues! they knew what a trial they were preparing for me.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir, you wiſh to ſee Major Bloomville, or his lady?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: No, ſweet lady; if thou art Miſs Clairville, my buſineſs is with thee: Canſt thou lend me thine ear for half an hour?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Will you have the goodneſs to let me know from whom I receive a requeſt ſo uncommon?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: And is there no one ſtriking lineament, by which thou canſt recognize the father, from his reſemblance to the ſon?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Hah! Sir?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: It were a ſin, young lady, to keep thee in a moment's painful ſuſpenſe: My name is Ralph Maitland, Miſs Clairville, and I am very much at thy ſervice, I aſſure thee.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Amazement!

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I am the father of a headſtrong boy, who has given thee much uneaſineſs; and I have to thank thee for the exerciſe of a degree of moderation, which is very ſeldom found among the catalogue of a woman's virtues.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Can I believe my ears?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Give them full credit, my dear; thou ſhalt hear nothing but truth from Ralph Maitland.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: This is a very unexpected viſit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Be compoſed, Miſs Eliza: We have, perhaps, hitherto been a mutual terror to each other; but henceforward I requeſt thee to know me for thy friend.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: My friend, Sir! O how ſoothing is that tender appellation! how balmy to the wounded boſom of the orphan Eliza!

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: And haſt thou been ſo deeply wounded, Eliza?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you ſee before you the daughter of misfortune and of ſufferance; alas! I know no other parents.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Young lady, I adviſe thee to take comfort; I confeſs obligations to thee; and I aſſure thee, that I would willingly go almoſt any lengths to ſerve thee.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Your countenance, Sir, is a pleaſing index of the goodneſs of your mind.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Be aſſured, Miſs Clairville, that I lament every circumſtance that oppoſes my ſtyling myſelf thy father.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Alas! Sir, to hail the venerable name of Father, was not reſerved for the poor Eliza; my infant tongue was never taught to liſp it; and in no moment has my maturer years, with unauthorized preſumption, aſpired to ſo vaſt an acquiſition.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Intereſting woman! henceforward I acquit my ſon!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Alas! Sir, I ſhould reckon your cenſure of that good young man as a ſerious calamity.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Then he ſhall not have my cenſure, Madam; for I will never contribute to thy inquietude.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: You are unexpectedly kind, Sir; but for me, accuſtomed to misfortunes, I have learned to bear them; my life has been a life of humiliation, and my moſt arduous ſtruggles to ſubmit to that neceſſity which deſtiny hath impoſed.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: By my ſerenity, a faſcinating girl!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Yet I have had friends, Sir; with gratitude I make this confeſſion; and the privilege of ranking Mr. Maitland in the number, is a circumſtance which furniſhes a relief, that is, on the preſent occaſion, truly neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: If I have ever, Miſs Clairville, given thee a moment's pain, I repent it from my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: And I, Sir, take leave to make the ſame acknowledgment: An interference with your plans has ever been foreign from my intention.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: I doubt it not, Madam. Wilt thou permit one queſtion? Has my ſon's departure thy approbation?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir, I have no right to give an opinion reſpecting his movements.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; friendſhip alone will authorize thee; and, as I reſpect thy judgment, I take the liberty to ſolicit thy ſentiments on a ſtep ſo important as his contemplated tour.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: You do me too much honour, Sir; but, as I feel a degree of confidence in your indulgence, I will ſay, that I think young men of obſervation cannot fail of reaping advantage from a knowledge of the world.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Unexampled prudence! But perhaps, Miſs Eliza, thou doſt not love, or, as young ladies phraſe it, thou haſt no preference for my ſon?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Hah! Sir?

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Canſt thou, Miſs Clairville, riſe ſo far ſuperior to the forms and faſhions of thy ſex, as to tell me plainly, how thy heart ſtands in regard to my ſon?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Circumſtanced as I am, Sir, your queſtion, it muſt be owned, is a little ſingular.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: It is ſo, Madam; but my freedom is a proof of my eſteem.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: To be diſtinguiſhed by you, Sir, muſt unqueſtionably be highly gratifying to me.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Conſider me as an old man, and do not heſitate.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: I have ever reverenced years, Sir.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Do not evade my queſtion, Madam.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: I will not make a merit with you, Sir, for an avowal which will be entitled to no praiſe. From the firſt dawn of my reaſon, I have been accuſtomed to admire virtue, even to a degree of enthuſiaſm; and I have been taught to feel a ſtrong predilection in favour of every genteel and graceful accompliſhment.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Well, Miſs Clairville.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: And I do not wiſh to conceal, that I have not felt my attachment to the virtues and the graces diminiſh, becauſe they happen to be perſonified by Charles Maitland.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: And this ingenuous declaration thou doſt not wiſh to conceal?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: No, Sir; for, not chooſing to preſent myſelf as a candidate for matrimonial life, I care not who knows, that I have no heart to give.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: But it is very natural for a young woman to contemplate an eſtabliſhment by wedlock.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, Sir; but, as I believe there are joys and ſorrows peculiar to every ſituation in life, and, as I have conceived that it is not ſo much the part, as the acting well that part, which entitles the performer to reſpectability, ſo I am determined to reſt ſatisfied with that character in the Drama, in which the great Manager ſeems to have caſt me my lot.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Admirable young woman!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Your approbation, Sir, is truly ſoothing.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Thou haſt thought very deeply, Madam, and made uncommon proficiency.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Adverſity, Sir, is an excellent ſchool.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.stage: [Walks about irreſolute, and appears much moved, after which he ſays:]
sp.p:
I have conceived, Miſs Clairville, that there was a natural beauty in propriety, an unalterable rule of right, and an eternal fitneſs of
things; nor will I yet relinquiſh my principles. Oppoſition to thee, enchanting maid, muſt conſtitute the extreme of obſtinacy; while, in thy lovely boſom, every virtue hath found a calm and happy aſylum.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Alas! Sir; you little know the imbecility of that heart which you would thus exalt.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt weep no more, my love—Know me henceforth as thy protecting father—the wiſhes of my ſon have now the fulleſt ſanction.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Amazement!

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Wilt thou not accept me as thy paternal friend?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: On my knees, Sir, I ſupplicate eternal ſunſhine on that dear paternal boſom—but know, Sir, that my ſacred, my irrevocable vow is regiſtered in heaven—I can never wear the envied title of your daughter, except a miracle ſhould render me the equal of your ſon; nor can even the wiſhes of Mr. Maitland recal the ſolemn hour which witneſſed a tranſaction, that renders his unexampled condeſcenſion forever ineffectual.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing! What haſt thou done, Eliza?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Forgive me, Sir; but, fearing that my tenderneſs would one day betray my reſolution, I bound myſelf by ties indiſſoluble.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: My perſevering obſtinacy has undone my ſon! Riſe, Eliza, dear, raſh, heroic, and uncommon girl! What ſtep remaineth to be taken?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: To ſubmit to deſtiny, Mr. Maitland; and remember that this life is but a paſſage to a better ſcene of things.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: It is a hard neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: You accuſe me of raſhneſs, Sir: You behold in me an orphan, friendleſs, poor, and claiming no natural protector! nor did I ever yet behold the being, whom I could challenge as relation! Conſider, Sir, is ſuch a female a fit companion for your ſon? Subordination, rank and degree, are of divine original; the lines are juſtly drawn; and he who breaks the rank aſſigned him by his Creator, is ſurely an aggreſſor.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Dear, uncommon girl! never were my own ſentiments ſo well expreſſed before—it were a crime of no inferior dye, to urge thee further—I cannot even wiſh thee to relinquiſh ideas, originating in divine propriety. But what, Miſs Clairville, are thy plans? Wilt thou permit me to regard thee as the daughter of my affection?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: My utmoſt gratitude is due to Mr. Maitland—But, although orphanaged with my firſt breath, I have received from ſtrangers that kind of education which ſecures my independence.

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: High-ſoul'd girl! it is impoſſible to faſten on thee the ſhadow of an obligation! Doſt thou expect to ſee my ſon before his departure?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: I do, Sir: As if in love with anguiſh, we have appointed this evening to exchange the laſt farewel!

sp.speaker: Maitl.
sp.p: Charming frankneſs! Admirable young lady! I tear myſelf from thee. Thou haſt made large inroads on that calm equality of diſpoſition, which it hath been the ſtudy of my whole life to cultivate; and I haſten from thee, to recover that firmneſs of which I ſtand ſo much in need. Accept, Miſs Clairville, my cordial benediction.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: May Heaven grant you peace, Sir. [Exit Mr. Maitland precipitately, and much diſordered.] My ſoul has been too highly wrought, and the retirement of my chamber is neceſſary to reſtore me to the power of aſſuming a calm which I ſhall never feel.

div.stage: SCENE—An Apartment in Miſs Dorinda Scornwell's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Miſs. Sc.
sp.p: And ſo, Jenny, you ſay that Mr. Charles Maitland is really going to flee his country?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: O yes, Ma'am, ſartingly.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: But where didſt thou get thy knowledge, Jenny?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p:
Why, you know, Ma'am, you ſent me to Mrs. Lacewell's for a new head—and ſo, ſeeing a
crowd of people about Maſter Maitland's houſe, what does I do but pop my head in for a few moments, and there I found the whole houſe in tears, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: And pray, could your ingenuity deviſe no cauſe why the whole houſe ſhould be in tears, except the departure of the young gentleman?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: You ſhall hear, Ma'am. Maſter Robert was in a piteous taking—and ſo, ſays I, what is the matter? ſays I. Why, ſays they, Maſter Charles is going to leave us, ſays they; and we ſhall all break our hearts, Miſs Jenny, ſays they.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: A mighty important matter to break hearts, indeed!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why, ſo I thought, Ma'am; but it didn't become a ſervant, as I was, to ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: And pray, did not your curioſity inquire the reaſon of his departure?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: O yes, Ma'am; and they ſays, Ma'am, how that it is all for the love of Miſs Clairville.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Nonſenſe—that creature!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why, ſo I thought, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: It is really intolerable, that ſervants ſhould give themſelves ſuch liberties; but thus it is, they are eternally fabricating motives for the conduct of their betters.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why, ſo I thought, Ma'am—'Tis quite intolerant, ſays I, and impoſſible beſides—But they ſays, that old Mr. Maitland will never conſent to the match, and that he is willing young Mr. Maitland ſhould go to the wars, in hopes that it will break the neck of it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: To the wars, Jenny?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am; for they ſays, as how that nobody goes over the ſeas, in theſe trepidation times, without fighting, Ma'am—ſo young Mr. Maitland may ſtand a chance of getting a wooden leg, or, may be, have his head chopped off by the Gluttoner, who, they ſays, is ſo greedy as to ſwallow a thouſand heads for a breakfaſt—and then, I thinks, Ma'am, he will pay very dear for the love of Miſs Clairville.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Why, ſo I ſaid, Ma'am—It is the hyperdiſtic of folly, ſays I.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Flee his country, indeed! Let me hear no more of it, I charge you, Jenny.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: No, truly, Ma'am—and I told them all this—Says I, Mr. Charles, ſays I, knows better than all that there; and if he might have Miſs Dorinda Scornwell, I am ſure ſhe is better than ſhe, every day ſhe riſes, ſays I; and a more richer, and a more prettier, and a more handſomer lady into the bargain—and, ſays I, if ſhe is a little older, what of that, ſays I, we cannot be always babies.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Amazing!

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am, I did not ſpare them—not I—and I told them it was all as falſity as falſity could be; for that you were never deſirous to marry Maſter Charles in all your born days.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing! Where will your impertinence end? [outer bell rings.] Take yourſelf to the door, Miſs Impudence, and ſee if there is no meſſage for me.

The ignorance of this wench is intolerable; yet I cannot ſay that I feel perfectly indifferent with regard to this extraordinary decampment: Maitland was once my favourite; and, were it not for the attention paid me by the irreſiſtible Colonel, I ſhould ſtill think it worth while to throw ſome impediments in his way—But what a captivating ſucceſſor is Colonel Mellfont; deſcended from a noble family, and of princely fortunes—it is true, he is my ſenior; but maturity hath its advantages—there can be no doubt entertained of my conqueſt of the Colonel's heart; his being here is a ſtrong evidence, and his mark'd politeneſs at the aſſembly laſt evening, is proof poſitive.
Leave the room, Impertinence.

sp.speaker: [Miſs Sc. reads.]
sp.p:
"Colonel Mellfont will not approach Miſs Dorinda Scornwell with compliments, preſuming on former acquaintance, he offers his reſpectful
regards, and being extremely impatient to preſent himſelf before her, having a very tender intereſt to plead, he takes leave to requeſt the honour of a private conference. If Colonel M—is fortunate enough to obtain Miſs Scornwell's permiſſion, he will wait on her, previous to the appointment for the afternoon."
O the dear, dear paper!
sp.stage: [Preſſes it to her lips, and rings clamorouſly.
sp.p: Is the man who brought this billet, gone, Jenny?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: He waits for an anſwer, Ma'am. [ſullenly.]

sp.speaker: Miſs Sc.
sp.p: Return my beſt compliments—No—ſtop—I will write—but that will look too forward—let me ſee—Yes, it muſt be a verbal meſſage—Do you hear?—My beſt compliments to Colonel Mellfont, and I ſhall be at home to receive him.

Now ſhall I be the envy of the whole town—the ladies will ſo rail—the gentlemen will ſo ogle—and at plays, balls, and card parties, I ſhall aſſume ſuch a well bred indifference, ſtare ſo confidently, and inſult my inferiors with an air ſo genteel, ſo careleſs, and ſo delectably imperious, that it will be divinely charming!—Bloomville will abſolutely break her heart—ha, ha, ha! Poor thing! her fortunes have long been on the decline—But I will trip to my dreſſing-room, conſult my glaſs, and ſet my features in the beſt imaginable order.

div.stage: SCENE—Another Apartment in Miſs Scornwell's Lodgings—Room highly decorated.

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: Heigh-day! the houſe alone here—but I'll ſoon make myſelf heard.
By Jupiter, a pretty wench. Hark'ye, ſweetheart, will you tell your lady, that her faithful ſoldier petitions for an interview?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: O yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt. F.
sp.p: There is nothing like doing things genteelly—Why, Doctor Johnſon would never have figured ſo wonderfully, if he had not ſtudied the graces. Let me ſee—ſhould I become a favourite with Miſs Scornwell, my fortune is made forever! and—and—I will live—O! how I will live!—Why, not even Dean Swift himſelf, was ever a politer man, or a fonder lover, than I will be.
